description: NPR takes listeners on a tour of the world’s biggest music fest: 200,000+ campers in a muddy field, rocking out. In recent years, Glastonbury has gone plastic-free, family-friendly and accessible for all.
title: The Glastonbury Festival goes environmental and family friendly

description: A rare white-colored buffalo calf was born in Yellowstone National Park this spring. It's interesting for tourists, but many Native Americans see it as the fulfillment of a prophecy.
title: For Native Americans, the birth of a rare white bison is a blessing and a warning

description: The U.S. Supreme Court issued multiple consequential decisions on Thursday, on everything from opioids to ozone pollution.
title: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority curtailed the SEC’s ability to impose fines

description: One in three convicted women are held in jail rather than prison, compared to about 1 in 10 of all convicted people. But compared to prisons, jails tend to have fewer resources and support systems.
title: Study shows incarcerated women experience different conditions than men

description: The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday temporarily blocked the Environmental Protection Agency’s “Good Neighbor Plan", which was designed to protect downwind states from air pollution.
title: U.S. Supreme Court blocks the EPA’s plan to combat interstate air pollution

description: The Supreme Court struck down a controversial Purdue Pharma bankruptcy plan, affecting compensation to thousands of opioid victims and sending legal shockwaves through the U.S. bankruptcy system.
title: Supreme Court tosses out bankruptcy plan for Purdue Pharma and Sackler family

description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Republican strategist Doug Heye and Democratic strategist Faiz Shakir about the stakes for Thursday's presidential debate.
title: Biden and Trump go head to head tonight. What are the stakes?

description: A wildfire in southern New Mexico threatens to wipe out a tourist town's busy season, while mudslides from a two-year-old burn scar in the north have created a drinking water crisis in another.
title: Fires, floods have New Mexico reeling from multiple disasters

description: President Biden and former President Donald Trump are set to take the stage at 9 p.m. ET Thursday for the first presidential debate of the 2024 general election.
title: Biden and Trump will debate tonight. Follow NPR for live coverage

description: A year ago, she packed what she could, helped her mother, who's in a wheelchair, into the car and drove all night to find a haven. In the U.S. to accept an award, she talks about her country's crisis.
title: Why this humanitarian leader carries the key to the home she abandoned in Sudan

description: When's the election? Who's running? Here's a short primer on Iran's vote for president.
title: Here's what to know about Iran's presidential election

description: The first 400 Kenyan police arrived in Haiti this week, part of a multinational force that will attempt to bring stability back the country. Gangs control most of Haiti's capital, Port-au-Prince. But the Kenyan police arrived in Haiti as the same police force was firing on protesters in Kenya's capital, Nairobi. We hear about what is happening both in Haiti and in Kenya.
title: Can Kenyan Police Stabilize Haiti?

description: A woman says Robert Morris, prominent evangelical pastor, former Trump religious adviser and founder of Gateway Church, sexually abused her as a child in the 1980s. Morris has resigned from Gateway.
title: The scandal roiling one of the nation's biggest megachurches, explained

description: New York Times political correspondent Shane Goldmacher says the debate will look different from the one four years ago, with no audience and mics that can be muted should things get unwieldy.
title: Debate between Biden and Trump is expected to be a test of competence and character

description: Among the court's opinions was a 6-3 ruling to temporarily allow abortions in medical emergencies in Idaho. The opinion was erroneously posted on the court's website Wednesday.
title: Supreme Court delivers opinions affecting abortion rights, emissions standards and more

description: In a 5-4 decision, the court granted the states' application to put the rule on hold while the case proceeds in the lower courts.
title: Supreme Court halts EPA’s 'Good Neighbor Plan'

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks with Democrat George Latimer, who won a New York primary battle against U.S. Rep. Jamaal Bowman, after the most expensive House primary campaign ever.
title: George Latimer on winning the most expensive primary race in U.S. House history

description: The moment marked the highlight of a Native American ceremony to commemorate the calf's birth that  featured the retelling of how a mysterious woman brought a message of reassurance during hard times.
title: Tribes honor the birth of rare white buffalo and reveal its name: Wakan Gli

description: With the presidential candidates debate nearing, we present the final installment of our voter's debate prep series. Today we cover foreign policy and abortion.
title: Voter prep for Biden-Trump debate: Where they stand on foreign policy, abortion

description: A top military general in Bolivia on Wednesday attempted to overthrow the government. The failed coup was put down quickly and the general was arrested.
title: Over a 3-hour period in Bolivia, a coup attempt is launched and then quickly quelled

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to Rev. William Barber II ahead of the Poor People's Campaign march. His book is "White Poverty: How Exposing Myths About Race and Class Can Reconstruct American Democracy."
title: A prominent Black pastor says white poverty doesn’t get enough attention

description: Although the color barrier was broken decades ago in Major League baseball, there are few black players in college baseball and even fewer coaches.
title: Why the dearth of Black college baseball coaches is a problem

description: The Ukrainian soldiers are on a U.S tour to thank Americans for the latest round of military aid to Ukraine -- and to court new support.
title: Ukrainian soldiers, who are also musicians, are on a thank you tour in the U.S.

description:
At 40, Lena Waithe already has an impressive legacy, with dozens of writing, acting and production credits. She was the first Black woman to win an Emmy for comedy writing (for Master of None). And she's also the creator of The Chi, which is just wrapping its sixth season. She tells Rachel one of her core beliefs is a lesson from The Wizard of Oz. They also discuss being bad at being wrong.

To listen sponsor-free, access bonus episodes and support the show, sign up for Wild Card+ at plus.npr.org/wildcard
title: Lena Waithe's religion is 'The Wizard of Oz.' Here's what she learned from it.

description: Levels of methane have increased particularly quickly since 2020. Livestock account for about 32% of human-caused methane emissions, the U.N. Environment Program says.
title: Gassy cows and pigs will face a carbon tax in Denmark, the first country to do so
